text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review tomahawk Oddfellows
tomahawk is an experimental and
alternative rock band this is their new
full-length LP and the band started as a
collaborative effort between Dwayne
Denison of the band the Jesus lizard and
fantastic multi-talented vocalist my pen
vocal phenom really as well as Trevor
Dunn who has also worked with Mike
Patton and groups such as mr. bungle and
who some of you may remember as playing
upright bass on quite a few tracks off
that new Melvin's album and something I
didn't even realize until this review
because I'm a complete fool it is
actually that this band features the
drummer from helmet and battles so I
mean because of all this experience and
all the numerous groups that all of
these people have taken part in over the
years I mean this is just not tomahawks
4th full-length album but really a group
of guys with just years and years and
years of rock and experimental rock
experience coming together to create a
full-length LP between these four guys
there are just too many different bands
and projects to count and some of them
completely different than others I mean
dudes like Mike Patton versatility is
pretty much their calling card not to
mention the fact that this band's last
LP had some really strong Native
American music influences however on
this new LP tomahawk seems to kind of
abandon what they did on the LP
anonymous they go back to their
experimental and alternative rock ways
but maybe with a slightly catchy or edge
on some tracks I mean so catchy and
straightforward I actually kind of feel
like I'm listening to what potentially
could have been a Faith No More single
back in the day mainly with tracks such
as stone letter but of course that is
just kind of one side of this new album
being a Patton fronted project it should
be assumed that this record overall is
is pretty versatile and jumps all over
the place stylistically and emotionally
all over this LP there are different
singing styles levels of weirdness
songwriting approaches as if the album
title were like a reference to what
these 13 songs feel like as a group but
odd fellow still is not really the
weirdest album that you're ever going to
run across I mean even at
weirdest tomahawk is able to kind of
keep all of the tracks on this album
around the two to four minute mark
now even though alternative rock is not
the most shocking adventurous or
exciting of genres
I feel like tomahawk makes a pretty
convincing argument for the exact
opposite they are able to sort of
adventure outside of the box on a lot of
tracks here but still stick to
alternative rocks modern catchy hooks
and riffs the opening track on here Odd
Fellows has this 7/8 timing on the verse
with this really awesome kind of heavy
weird just odd guitar riff that is sort
of iced with these really spooky grimy
vocals from Mike Patton but once the
band kicks into the chorus the vocals
start kind of soaring this very close
harmony that I think an Allison chains
fan would really appreciate the tracks
tone letter is kind of like a slightly
sped up piece of arena rock without this
really huge sense of grandiosity but
still very melodic I could see members
of the band
back-to-back singing into the microphone
and unison on this one but Mike Patton
brings that weirdness and by having kind
of this strange raspy 'no stew his voice
over the verses it's a nice contrast the
song southpaw goes down the same Road
but maybe is a little bit on the corny
er side especially with the lyrics and
is kind of my least favorite track on
this LP as a result the song IOU quietly
builds in intensity and in harmony with
these really awesome guitar leads the
song itself feels you know sort of
strange tortured but the atmosphere the
reverb thrown on this track sort of
brings it to a another level of
cavernous sadness the song a thousand
eyes comes on slow as well and it just
sort of you know hit me especially on
this song sometimes tomahawk is just
really really great at sort of building
that intensity in in a slower moment I
love the pace that these guys are able
to work at but still kind of keep the
track engaging and of course their spots
on this LP where Mike Patton kind of
steals the show like on the song white
hats black hats where his just gravelly
voice which he kind of pulls out
specifically for this track and maybe
another one on here too
sounds maniacal and and in a way kind of
cartoony but sort of villainous as well
but as far as just major downsides
overall for this LP I think this album
after numerous listens kind of exposed
itself to me to be incredibly incredibly
front-loaded I mean really in my opinion
the most exciting tracks and pretty much
all the new ground I guess for tomahawk
is broken on the first half of the album
on the other half the album you have
songs that are either maybe a bit
shorter kind of rehashing ideas that
were earlier on the album or in some
cases featured in other projects that
these band members are in in my opinion
these song baby let's play is just I
mean really underwhelming the way that
it just me Anders I mean really it's
kind of like staring at dust flow
through this beam of sunlight coming
down from the window you notice it and
it's kind of you know beautiful the way
things kind of hang in the balance and
that beam of light but still it gets
kind of you know after a while and the
closing track on here is this kind of
weird blend of hard rock and and surf
rock with vocals from Mike Patton really
this is the only part in the entire
album where I actually find his singing
to be sort of borderline obnoxious I
mean it feels kind of tagged on to the
end of the LP because it doesn't really
feel like it would flow into any other
song here Odd Fellows is definitely one
of Tomahawks more diverse efforts but
they're just some songs on here that
don't reach that experimental or
adventurous level that I've always heard
from these guys I'm feeling a strong six
to a light seven on this album if you've
given it a listen did you love it did
you hate it
why and what do you think I should
review next
Anthony Fantana tomahawk forever
